awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Experimental and Computational Approaches to Tailor Properties of Additively Manufactured Semi-Crystalline Polymers
awd_abstract_narration:
Material extrusion, a form of polymer additive manufacturing in which a filament is extruded layer-by-layer onto a bed, can manufacture components with geometric complexity far beyond that possible with conventional manufacturing methods. Building the part in layers, which enables great geometric freedom, also limits the mechanical integrity of the printed part. The bonding quality between printed layers yields parts with lower mechanical strength than if they were manufactured by traditional molding methods. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research project seeks to understand how polymer properties and processing conditions interact, and how they can both be manipulated to enhance interlayer bonding in material extrusion additive manufacturing. The knowledge gained will be leveraged to both tailor polymer properties for additive manufacturing processes, and to print components with mechanical properties appropriate for functional applications. Success will greatly enhance the competitiveness of the US additive manufacturing base by providing a pathway towards the manufacture of cost effective, functional polymeric components. This award will also facilitate training of the future workforce; both graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in the research activities and will gain experience in advanced manufacturing and polymer science. As this is an industry-university collaborative project with Henkel Corporation, the students involved will also gain an understanding of industrial challenges and drivers. Planned workshops on polymer additive manufacturing will disseminate the knowledge to industries seeking new opportunities in this manufacturing arena.

This research will test the hypotheses that interlayer diffusion is a function of the difference between extrusion temperature and glass transition temperature, and that weld strength is dependent on the difference between the glass transition temperature and melt temperature as well as temperature-dependent wetting. This necessitates an understanding of the thermal characteristics of the material and the additive manufacturing process, and how they affect physical and mechanical properties of a printed structure. Towards this goal, three major research tasks will be undertaken: 1. Determine the role of the difference between the glass transition and melt temperatures in weld strength and residual stress of printed semi-crystalline polymers; 2. Understand the impact of crystallization kinetics on the crystalline morphology formed in additively manufactured structures; 3. Understand how glass reinforcement affects crystallization, heat transfer, and mechanical properties. By understanding the role of assembly conditions on resulting physical and mechanical properties, the work will lead to improved and tailorable physical and mechanical polymer properties essential to structure functionality. This research will also provide guidance in how to formulate polymers for additive manufacturing, based on thermal and physical properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Material extrusion, a form of polymer additive manufacturing in which a filament is extruded layer-by-layer onto a bed, is the most widely used method of additive manufacturing and can manufacture components with geometric complexity far beyond that possible with conventional manufacturing methods. Building the part in layers, which enables great geometric freedom, also limits the mechanical integrity of the printed part and can result in parts with lower mechanical strength than if they were manufactured by traditional molding methods. The project investigated how semicrystalline polymer properties and processing conditions interact, and how they can both be manipulated to enhance interlayer bonding in polymer material extrusion additive manufacturing.

This project tested the hypotheses that interlayer diffusion is a function of the difference between extrusion temperature and glass transition temperature, and that weld strength is dependent on the difference between the glass transition temperature and melt temperature as well as temperature-dependent wetting. Interlayer diffusion was found to depend on extrusion temperature, layer time, printed road dimensions, and overall structural dimensions. The difference between the glass transition temperature and melt temperature, as well as the crystallization kinetics and temperature-dependent wetting, were key drivers of the weld strength relative to a material’s bulk strength. Testing of these hypotheses necessitated an understanding of the thermal characteristics of the material and the additive manufacturing process, and how they affect physical and mechanical properties of a printed structure. Towards this goal, three major research tasks were undertaken:

1. Determine the role of the difference between the glass transition and melt temperatures in weld strength and residual stress of printed semi-crystalline polymers. This work investigated material extrusion of a semicrystalline polyamide-based hot melt adhesive produced by Henkel Corporation, our industry partner, with sub-ambient glass transition temperature, intermediate melting temperature, and low recrystallization temperature. Optimized print parameters, in combination with the material’s low viscosity, resulted in void-free prints that exhibited isotropic tensile properties comparable to or better than compression molded values. This work broadens the materials for and properties that can be achieved with material extrusion and demonstrates that hot melt adhesives can be used to additively manufacture optically transparent, flexible structures capable of >1,200% strain to failure.

2. Understand the impact of crystallization kinetics on the crystalline morphology formed in additively manufactured structures. The crystallization kinetics of two materials for material extrusion, the hot melt adhesive and a polyamide copolymer, were compared. The hot melt adhesive crystallized slowly and with small crystallites, but crystallization could continue at room temperature. The polyamide copolymer crystallized more quickly and to a higher extent, which could cause warping in printed structures. Crystallization kinetics data was then incorporated into thermal models capable of predicting relative amounts of crystallization throughout a printed structure and results were validated with experiments.  

3. Understand how glass reinforcement affects crystallization, heat transfer, and mechanical properties. The properties of structures printed from the hot melt adhesive and a chopped glass fiber-filled form of the hot melt adhesive were compared. The addition of glass fiber reduced weld strength, and this effect was more significant in thinner samples. Longer toolpaths/layer times resulted in higher warpage and decreased tensile strength of the hot melt adhesive, but did not affect the tensile properties of the glass-filled system. Glass fibers prevented warpage and improved dimensional stability of initial layer. The glass-filled system is also stronger, which makes this material more appropriate for larger scale applications in which there is a high thermal mass and slumping is a significant printing challenge.

A data science supplement focused on identifying what kinds and amounts of data are necessary to train machine learning algorithms to predict properties in material extrusion. Active learning approaches were found to reduce the number of samples necessary to adequately train a model.    

By understanding the role of assembly conditions on resulting physical and mechanical properties, the work will lead to improved and tailorable properties essential to structure functionality. This project also provides guidance in how to formulate polymers for additive manufacturing, based on thermal and physical properties. The knowledge gained can leveraged to both tailor polymer properties for additive manufacturing processes, and to print components with mechanical properties appropriate for functional applications. The results from this project can be used to enhance the competitiveness of the US additive manufacturing base by providing a pathway towards fabrication of cost effective, functional polymeric components. The award also facilitated training of the future workforce; in total, three PhD students, one MS student, seven undergraduates, and three high school students were involved in the research activities and gained experience in additive manufacturing. As this is an industry-university collaborative project with Henkel Corporation, the students involved also gained an understanding of industrial challenges and drivers. A workshop on additive manufacturing disseminated knowledge to industries in other areas of advanced manufacturing seeking new opportunities enabled by additive manufacturing.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2022
Modified by: Amy Peterson
por.por_txt_cntn:
Material extrusion, a form of polymer additive manufacturing in which a filament is extruded layer-by-layer onto a bed, is the most widely used method of additive manufacturing and can manufacture components with geometric complexity far beyond that possible with conventional manufacturing methods. By understanding the role of assembly conditions on resulting physical and mechanical properties, the work will lead to improved and tailorable properties essential to structure functionality. This project also provides guidance in how to formulate polymers for additive manufacturing, based on thermal and physical properties. The knowledge gained can leveraged to both tailor polymer properties for additive manufacturing processes, and to print components with mechanical properties appropriate for functional applications. The results from this project can be used to enhance the competitiveness of the US additive manufacturing base by providing a pathway towards fabrication of cost effective, functional polymeric components. The award also facilitated training of the future workforce; in total, three PhD students, one MS student, seven undergraduates, and three high school students were involved in the research activities and gained experience in additive manufacturing. As this is an industry-university collaborative project with Henkel Corporation, the students involved also gained an understanding of industrial challenges and drivers. A workshop on additive manufacturing disseminated knowledge to industries in other areas of advanced manufacturing seeking new opportunities enabled by additive manufacturing.
